developmentContext.title: Development Context
developmentContext.content: The country consists of two volcanic islands, Saint Kitts and Nevis (KNA) with a population of 53,104 persons. Basseterre is the capital located on the larger island of Saint Kitts, and Charlestown is the capital of the smaller island of Nevis, which is located 2 miles away, across a shallow channel called The Narrows. The islands carry on small-scale production of crops, including rice, yams, bananas and cotton, but its present economy is based primarily on tourism. Within the last few years, there has been substantial expansion of the tourism sector, additional cruise ports, hotels, national events and attractions; creating livelihoods across the island. The majority of the islands’ inhabitants live near the coastline, as the interior tends to be extremely rugged and steep. The country has a high literacy rate at 97.8 percent and a low unemployment rate of 5.1 percent.

successesInDevelopment.title: Successes in Development
successesInDevelopment.content:
Saint Kitts and Nevis’ HDI value for 2019 is 0.779— which puts the country in the high human development category. Between 2005 and 2019, Saint Kitts and Nevis’ HDI value increased from 0.711 to 0.779, an increase of 9.6 percent. Between 1990 and 2019, Saint Kitts and Nevis’ life expectancy at birth increased by 7.4 years, mean years of schooling increased by 1.5 years and expected years of schooling increased by 1.1 years. Saint Kitts and Nevis’ GNI per capita increased by about 65.4 percent between 1990 and 2019.

The Ministry of Tourism has earmarked restoration of natural resources as a key element of its plan to develop eco-tourism, aiming to attract new interest groups. Community-based tourism perfectly aligns with conservation of biodiversity and creation of livelihoods.

The Department of Environment embarked on community awareness training to stimulate action on reforestation and restoration of biodiversity. The Department of Marine Resources, introduced legislation (Fisheries, Aquaculture and Marine Resources Act of 2016), to support activities that develop an aquaculture environment, increase fish production and address ocean pollution.

challengesInDevelopment.title: Challenges in Development
challengesInDevelopment.content:
The efforts to diversify the economy are severely restricted by constraints of market size, limited natural resources, and high production costs. The Federation is vulnerable to existing climatic conditions, particularly droughts and hurricanes, and will need to build national capacity to respond to the challenges presented by global climate change.

Pressure for agricultural land has caused small farmers to clear forested plots along slopes for farming, causing deforestation, soil erosion and water pollution. In KNA water resources are vulnerable to sea level rise and temperature increase leading to higher evaporation rates. Given the centrality of ground water sources to the national water supply, the problem of water resources is primarily one of keeping and protecting the underground water resources. Waste Management continues to be a growing concern. The increase in human settlements has resulted in a commensurate increase in the need for waste management services.
